Award.AwardTitle: Searching and Discovering New Physics at the ATLAS Experiment of LHC
Award.AbstractNarration: The California State University Fresno group participates in the ATLAS experiment at the CERN Large Hadron Collider. The research program focuses on jet physics, electroweak physics, Event Data Models and the development of Physics Analysis Tools. The group is also active in the R&D program for the upgrade of ATLAS, including muon detectors, and provides leadership for US Collaborators on ATLAS in the domain of Tier 3 computing. The Cal State Fresno program also provides an unusual opportunity for broadening participation through a consortium of thirteen CSU campuses. Through this structure, the CSU Fresno group offers masters-level graduate students and undergraduate students the opportunity to work at CERN with CSU and international ATLAS researchers in a broad spectrum of research projects at the energy frontier of physics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The CSU Fresno ATLAS group consists of one faculty (Yongsheng Gao, PI), one postdocs (Harinder Bawa), two IT engineer (Jay Fowler and Geoff King), one Ph.D student (Dengfeng Zhang from Shandong University of P. R. China), 3 Master students (Marijus Brazickas, Jimmy Gonzalez, and Victor Ruelas) and 13 undergraduate students (Aaron Bassill, Taylor Dinkins, Michael Dobbs, Ian Guerrero, Sarah Kroeker, Olivia Krohn, Annette Lopez, Jon Van Noort, Jeffrey Rowland, Fiona Pons, Daniel Turner, Ethan Villarama, and Geordan Waldman). The group’s activities on ATLAS includes: new physics searches, ATLAS Connect, ATLAS control room data quality and DAST shifts, FTK, operation of ATLAS pixel detector, global feature extractor (gFEX) of trigger upgrade, improving ATLAS event display, education and outreach, etc.

Bawa, Brazickas, Zhang, and the PI have been working on searching for new physics with Dijet final states. Since June of 2015, they have given a total of 29 presentations at ATLAS working group meetings, contributed to two ATLAS notes, and one ATLAS publication in PLB..

7 students (Brazickas, Gonzalez, Noort, Rowland, Ruelas, Turner, and Waldman) worked at CERN on ATLAS research projects from June to August of 2015. Ruelas and Rowland worked on ATLAS FTK during summer of 2015 with ATLAS collaborators from Stanford (Dr. Lauren Tomplins, Dr. Nikolina Ilic, etc.). Ruelas gave one presentation at ATLAS FTK working group meeting in Oct. of 2015. Gonzalez and Noort worked with Dr. Tancredi Carli from CERN on improving particle-based top quark definition. Brazickas worked with ATLAS physicists Avishek Chatterjee (University of Geneva) and Geraldine Conti (CERN) on heavy neutral lepton search. Turner worked with ATLAS physicists Matteo Bauce and Andrea Messina from Universitae INFN, Roma I on characterization of an innovative high level trigger based on Graphical Processing Units (GPU) for the muon identification. Waldman worked with ATLAS physicists Arturos Sanchez Pineda and Francesco Conventi from Universitae INFN, Napoli on development of web based pre-analysis tools which were the first version of a web based and cloud computing services to allow ATLAS physicists to do fast and very useful cut-based pre-analysis on a browser using real data and official MC. 10 students (Bassill, Dinkins, Dobbs, Gonzalez, Guerrero, Kroeker, Krohn, Lopez, Pons, and Villarama) arrived at CERN end of May this summer to work on ATLAS research projects until mid of August.

The CSU Fresno ATLAS group continues to contribute to the successful running of the ATLAS experiment. Since June of 2015, Bawa has taken 8 weeks of ATLAS Distributed Analysis Support Team (DAST) Class 2 shifts and the PI has taken 27.31 OTP of ATLAS Control Room Data Quality Class 1 shifts. The CSU Fresno ATLAS Tier 3 cluster which consists of ~408 cores and ~210TB storage was the first Tier 3 cluster on ATLAS CONNECT project and has been contributing to US ATLAS for the past year.

To provide the outstanding ATLAS/CERN opportunity to a wider CSU community, the PI has been building up the CSU Nuclear and Particle Physics Consortium (NUPAC) with the CSU Fresno ATLAS program as its center. CSU NUPAC now consists of 17 CSU campuses (Bakersfield, Channel Islands, Chico, Dominguez Hills, East Bay, Fresno, Humboldt, Long Beach, Los Angeles, Northridge, Pomona, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Francisco, San Luis Obispo, Sonoma, and Stanislaus).
